references.B09BRE01USGP: Brennan, T. C. and Holycross, A. T. 2009. A field guide to amphibians and reptiles in Arizona. Arizona Game and Fish Department. Phoenix, Arizona.
references.R09JON01USGP: Jones, L.C.C. and Lovich, R.E. (eds.). 2009. Lizards of the American Southwest: A Photographic Field Guide. Rio Nuevo Publishers, Tucson, Arizon. 567pp.
references.B92SIT01NAUS: Sites, J. W., Jr., et al. 1992. A review of phylogenetic hypotheses for lizards of the genus SCELOPORUS (Phrynosomatidae):implications for ecological and evolutionary studies. Bull. Am. Mus. Nat. Hist. (213):1-110.
references.B03STE01USGP: Stebbins, R.C. 2003. A field guide to western reptiles and amphibians.  Third Edition. Houghton Mifflin, Boston.
references.W12NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.

habitat_description:
In Arizona, this species is found in most habitats; from dry areas in the Plains and Great Basin Grassland and desert scrub to high elevation and even moist environments of mixed conifer forest, Ponderosa Pine Forest, and pinon and juniper woodlands (Jones and Lovich 2009). Also found in shrubby flatlands, foothills, mountain slopes, and grassy plains. It is associated with rock piles, boulders, fence posts, fallen trees and logs, and wood piles (Brennan and Holycross 2009). Leaché (2009) also reported the distribution of this species includes Utah, West Colorado, and Northwest New Mexico.

SW	-Chaparral, Great Basin desert scrub, semi desert grassland, Plains and Great Basin grassland, pinon Woodland, Juniper Woodland, mixed conifer forest, and Ponderosa Pine Forest
